text: They didn't get any money from Weird Tales, $100 a month, but they certainly did the best they could. Gernsback was less willing to pay. He paid, and finally I got a lawyer for the American Fiction Guild to collect what he only 20% around $300 and it must have been for about 60,000 words a copy one of the things I wanted to ask you about was you started off with a sort of fantasy science fiction story of metal men and then you went deeply into science fiction but I think one of your most fascinating things that I read was darker than you think what caused the change in your writing what causes Well, I'm not sure, except that people change and grow and sometimes decay and whatever. When I wrote Darker Than You Think, I was under psychoanalysis. I was in Hollywood. for the conclusion of it, I first went to Dr. Tedd at the Munninger Institute in Topeka and worked with him for about a year and broke off for a couple of years and decided I needed some more and moved to Beverly Hills in the meantime and stayed another year. The psychiatrist in the story is now reflects some attitudes toward Dr. Tidd. I think it's probably unfair or unfair to him to say that, but it seems to me that looking back now at the story and what he tries to say, Will Barbee starts up in terror of the forces of darkness, and in the end, he finds he is part of them. And that, in a way, is reflection of my own experience. I can remember a time when I felt that I was involved in a strong conflict between will and emotion where I made resolutions that were difficult to keep and felt sort of divided against myself. I feel that I got to be all better integrated so that I am no longer subconscious of internal conflicts or wanting to do things that I do not do or attempting to make resolutions that that I wouldn't be able to keep. I just have a degree of acceptance of myself, of the unconscious, of the whole human nature? That I didn't have. I think that's probably the basic emotional structure of the novel. You weren't attempting then to … Did you have any serious ideas about the lycanthropy, the werewolf, that that was the reason for it? that kind of genetic inheritance? Well, I think the lycanthropy is an excellent or apt or whatever symbol for, let's say, the quote, dark forces of the unconscious. And I didn't certainly have any serious, but belief in magic or lycanthropy It was pure fantasy or science fiction, but unfortunate invention because it was symbolic and expressive and so in its own way true. To go forward a little bit, another book I wanted to ask you about is Brother to Demon, Brother to Gods, more or less on genetic engineering and so forth. I took that book as fairly optimistic in its ending. I think it is. It was meant to be. I'm certainly interested in genetic engineering. It seems to me that well the big scientific event, well 40 years ago when it happened, was the splitting of the atom, and unraveling of DNA is, has somewhat more profound consequences when we began to realize them. And years ago, I wrote a novel, in which, well, so far as I know, but it invented the term genetic engineering, or it had probably been around in other works, called Dragon's Island. But that was published in 51, which was a couple of years before Watson and Craig made that great breakthrough. And then more recently, I decided to come back to it and to push the possibilities of genetic engineering as far as I could imagine them. Would you accept it? I mean, is it something you're for? Well, I don't think it's a matter of being for it or not. I think it's going to happen. I think that people are going to be opposed to it and there'll be conflicts and so forth, but assuming that science and technology remain alive, well, I think genetic engineering is going forward. It has so many possible uses in the manufacture of insulin, the manufacture of interferon, and the possibilities for, let's say, improving health and happiness, and comfort and longevity are so vast that you can't imagine people refusing to do it, and if we go ahead with it, it involves the potential of improving or changing and tinkering with the human germplasm and rebuilding the race itself. As I said, it's fascinating to watch, and in the story of us set up the Smithwick family as the creators and have them recreating their own children so they would be better genetic engineers generation after generation. I set up these four creations. The true men who were genetically perfect, who were happy and smart and peaceful and good citizens of society and the new men who were specialized for space or warfare or anything else. And the gods ruled and then discovering that the gods were created a little bit too much in the image of man so that there needs to be another creation to supplant the gods. And the gods naturally don't want to be supplanted. And it struck me that this was, let's say, a beautiful dramatic situation with the essence of conflict of conflict and discovery and revelation where these two naked kids on the preman reservation faced with the problem of keeping alive when the gods are after them to grow up and discover what they are and might make the old a man to replace the gods. It was just fun to do, let's say. And I wouldn't say that it's possible But I wouldn't say it's impossible. That is, I think that it is imaginative exploration of what could happen. Would you say in that book that man is sort of controlling his own evolution? Well, it seems to me we can control our own evolution. And that, in a way, is not very remarkable, because for many thousands of years, We've been controlling the evolution of horses and cattle and dogs and so forth, so that obviously human evolution can be controlled, and since we're discovering, let's say decoding the genetic message, where we can do it more effectively and genetically, effectively and efficiently, than it was already done before. What about, this isn't exactly the same kind of material, but it is in a way, that story on Guinevere for Everybody about cloning. Is cloning something you can foresee as possible or good? I can't really see any good in it or not much good anyway, but it seems to me it's possible we can already clone frogs and with continual refinement and laboratory processes and understanding and so forth I can see cloning human beings but a human clone as far as I can see is is essentially an identical or a queen and not a sort of supernatural second self. So, assuming that you had clones, it seems to me that they would have to be grown up individually and educated individually. And they would not be doppelgangers or second selves or instant duplicates of the donor, or whatever. You can't see why it shouldn't happen. It seems to me that there's a possibility of using the cloning technique to, for example, to grow a new heart that would be a perfect replacement of a normal heart because it's grown out of the same tissue and such things as this. It might be possible to grow a whole series of implants and replacements that would make make life go on almost essentially forever. As far as I know, the brain cells are not replaceable and they won't live forever. So I can't see that as a real way to immortality. One more question on this particular point. Say in reference to cloning or genetic engineering, would you say that there is no area of science that man, I mean man can monkey with anything he wants, is there anything which we shouldn't touch which would be wrong for science to meddle with or monkey with? Well I suppose I'm sort of a relativist, maybe I'm a Darwinian evolutionist. It's hard to find any absolute symbols or standards or whatever of what is wrong and right. If you look at the whole evolutionary picture why some things, patterns of growth and ways of behavior and so forth lead to the survival of the individual and the species and some don't. That's one available standard of behavior and if you look at that why the technology seems likely to survive and prevail unless they destroy themselves. And whatever is going to destroy the race is obviously bad in that way, and it seems to me when we open the atom, we're skating on thin ice, and there might be similar hazards in genetic engineering. That is, theoretically, we could design a form of life that would wipe us out. Maybe we will. Maybe we need the humanoids to keep us from doing that. That's what they're for. But personally, being a sort of individualist, I hate to give up completely to the humanoids. There is one more work. I keep forgetting about this one, the CT work, CT ship, CT shock. Is that the way that's pronounced, by the way? CT? Contra-terrine matter? Yes, it was abbreviated contra-terrine with the letters C and T, and I just spelled it out. That was a work I did for Kamel and I enjoyed doing it. I went to him with the idea for a series of stories about the planetary engineers who would terraform new worlds. That is, would rebuild them, tinker with the atmosphere, the chemistry, maybe the gravitation whatever, to make them suitable for human settlement. And Cummel suggested that some of these new worlds might be CT, that is, Aided Matter, which was pretty new to science fiction then. I was fascinated, and I did a series of stories and then a serial that eventually became two novels. Where did you come up with the concept terraform? Did you coin that word? As far as I know, I invented the word. My name is David and you began to recite a few such terms that I think I can claim credit for such as terraforming and psionics, and the android is distinct from Robert and so forth. Didn't the CT novel and the short stories lead into a syndicated strip in the newspapers? that was exciting adventures. I was sitting at my desk one day when a phone rang and the editor of the New York Sunday news was on the line and wanted to know if I would come to New York and write a comic strip. And I caught my breath and said I would, and they had read one of the CT novels reviewed in the New York Times by a rather superior reviewer, and said that the plot was pretty interesting, but the way of writing made it look like a science fiction comic strip. And this was in the early days of commercial TV, when people were turning on the tube on Sunday morning instead of writing the Sunday news. Somebody thought that if it had exclusive strips instead of syndicated strips that everybody else had. It might give them a competitive age. They originally planned for new comics including a Western and a Mystery and Adventure, I think, but the science fiction was the only one they did. It ran for three years, but eventually didn't turn out to be the answer to TV. the artist was Lee Elias who used to work with MLK Niff on Terry and the Pirates and has a nice clean cut style and was good with new and strange characters and good with machines and the thing was fun to do. My heart was broken when it ended because I'd come to enjoy getting my regular check. it was at that time that I went back part-time into the academic world. I started taking college courses while the strip was running because it didn't take all my time to write it. I asked for a graduate assistantship and math and they didn't have one, but I was was that I just stared to one in English which turned out to be a fortunate choice and the academic world did mesh very well with writing. It's wonderful to be paid to read good literature and talk about it with a congenial group of students. And I enjoyed teaching and found that I was able to continue writing during holidays and vacations. and maybe I learned a little bit more about literature and about people and so forth. It was a very happy experience. Didn't you also put together one of the first courses on science fiction? I think so. Mark Heligance at Colgate University wrote the first one that I knew about. It was written up in the National Server and I kept the article out I showed it to the curriculum committee and my chairman at Eastern and I got approval for a course. What time was that? That was, let's see, Helligus started his course in 1962 and I started mine in 1964 and taught it for a dozen years, spent part of those years doing all I could to promote academic science fiction elsewhere and accumulated descriptions of other courses and lectured and published articles and finally put together a textbook for science fiction teachers and anthology of articles by Likes of Asimov and Gwynn and Gunn and others that has finally been published I have a question about your own opinion this may not be a fair question to ask of an author, but do you have favorite books, favorite stories, characters, as you look back, that you would, say, like most to be remembered for? Many of my own. Yeah, on your own. Yes. I think darker than you think is probably the thing, the novel, that, let's say, fell into place most pleasingly. When I look back on it, it seems still to work. It's still engaging and still means something. Humanoids has been my most successful, most widely translated novel, but the original Novelette with folded hands said essentially what I wanted to say in more compact and satisfying ways so that I always felt the novelette was a better story than the novel. That, in a way, has been my most successful and popular work. The novelette has been reprinted many, many times. How many languages has the humanoid been translated into it? Well, I don't know, but most of the Western European languages and Japan, and let's see, it's just going into several Croatians and Hebrew. But it's gotten around. I want to add something about your working method. When you come up with a concept for a story, you know, whatever it is, you know, CT or humanoids, whatever, do you get a concept and then find a story to fit it, or do you have a story that you shove the concept into? Is there... Well, I'd like to say I think that it just grows. I often began with some sort of abstract idea, like the conflict or primitivism and progress, or whatever, and I looked for the essence of conflict in the basic idea, and then tried to find characters of forces that would embody this conflict, and in the early stages of it, why the whole thing is very flexible, almost flimsy. You can do anything to it if you want to, turn it inside out. But if it works, it gradually comes alive and the characters become real. They, until, they are, well, human beings that I feel that I know, and it sort of, change becomes very difficult to make. I noticed looking over some of your manuscripts at Eastern New Mexico University that you do revise. It seems to me that you had revised. Is that a normal process of your writing to go back over? More and more. In the beginning, I saw myself as a pulp writer. My idols in the pulp field were such figures as Max Brand, who was said to write 4,000 words every day, including Sundays and he sent it out in rough draft. The course of his life, he said it would have published between 30 and 40 million words. And I tried to do that for years, and sometimes believe it or not, it worked. Most of my work for several years was submitted in the first draft and often accepted and liked by the fans, but as time goes on, I change. The market changes. changes I become I guess more conscious of technique and the ways that things can go wrong. So now a day it's when I write a paragraph, I have a tendency to take it apart and rewrite it instead of going wrong, which was one reason for buying this new word processor, because it seems to facilitate the revision immensely. You compose on a monitor and if you don't like what you see there, where you can over-type it or delete it or whatever, and save whatever's good without having to re-type it. How do you keep up with science? You must have a fairly extensive scientific background, or any good science fiction writer must. Well, I've always been, as I said, fascinated with science as a sort of unfolding mystery. that is I want to know as much as I can about the nature and the origins of the universe. I subscribe to a whole group of magazines, Science News, Scientific American Science, which is the publication of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, which is, which I'm pretty technical, but some things I can read and understand. I subscribe to a couple of astronomy magazines. I subscribe to a couple of computer magazines. since I bought the word processor and occasionally I get off to other events. My wife and I attended the Jupiter flyby at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory March, a year ago, and got a short story out of that that I called it Descent into the Great Red Spot though I think that's changing the name of it and we've been invited back to the Saturn and fly by come November and something like that, which gives you an opportunity to see actual science at work, and science unfolding is about as exciting as anything could be. The Jupiter flyby, while the pictures of Jupiter and its satellites were coming in on the monitors, one every 48 seconds. Most of them you knew would never be seen again. And there were select some for more study, but most of them would disappear. And it was just exciting. It was like exploring a new solar system. These satellites up to that time had just been spots of light in the telescope, and at the nearest best approaches it was you could see details just a few kilometers across. And each satellite was different, with a different history, with different clues about the origins of itself and the whole solar system and maybe the universe. Things like that might make science as interesting as anything I know. To change the subject again, let's see, if I remember now, you have been president of the Science Fiction Writers Association, or you still are? I finished my second term less than a month ago. I hope now to get back to more science fiction. The term is for how long? Each term is for only one year. It was a very rewarding experience. I guess I have said before science fiction is a pretty small, friendly, close community and a lot of people in it have been good friends over the years. and it was an opportunity to try to do something for science fiction. But it took a bit of the time. What were your duties, if you don't mind me breaking in? We have about 500 members. We have all sorts of activities. One of the most important is a grievance committee that tries to, let's say, avoid difficulties with editors and publishers and so forth. but to make sure that they treat us right. We have the nebula awards that are given each year to recognize working the field. We attempt to also publicize and propagandize science fiction. And there are many, many people in our organization who devote a lot of priceless time and energy to this, but the whole thing has to be coordinated and people drop out and have to be replaced and misunderstandings develop that have to be somehow explained and new projects come along that need to be supported. There wasn't any one thing that took a great deal of time, but there was a continual flow of problems and minor decisions and so forth, so that every week I'd have to spend maybe a couple of days catching up on the mail and phone calls, and whatever. What are the criteria for membership? Does everybody who, is everybody automatically a member who publishes a story or does it have to take application or. you make application, and an affiliate member has to have at least one story professionally published, and an active member the requirement for that is three stories, short stories, or short works that doesn't have to be fiction stories or a longer works such as a novel or whatever. The deals now now, of forty dollars a year, and we have two publications, a monthly, well, between them, they're monthly, a forum that is essentially for the members with official business and market reports and whatever, and a bulletin that comes out four times a year that is devoted devoted to more general articles, background material on science and science fiction. And the members usually have privilege to attend the Safwa Suite at a convention and let's say membership is a sort of ticket to the club that I regard as exciting to belong to. You said there are some 500 members? Yes. That must be the largest, uh... obviously the largest it's ever been, probably. Yes, it's still growing steadily. The science fiction market, well, until the last year or so, was booming. Various publishers, paperback publishers, had regular plans to publish four, six, sometimes eight titles a month. that, Willie Charlie Brown of Locust was keeping a record of the books published and that kept growing until the total passed a thousand a year, about half re-print and half new, including fantasy as well as science fiction. I think that, well, since the depression, or whatever it was, where many publishers have cut back their schedules, it is a little harder for a new writer to break in than it was, but it's still a very profitable and exciting field compared to what it was. When there was one magazine, I got 25 bucks for my first story. Of course, the big money is from films and TV and such things as that. I know you said that it's hard for you to keep up with everything that's being published today, but do you have any particularly favorite authors, the younger ones, say, starting in the last 10 years or so, that you think are going to be valuable? Well, I don't follow well enough to say anything very intelligent. When I was teaching, I regarded Esther Le Guin's Left Hand of Darkness as the best recent novel and a great admirer of Heinlein, especially the early Heinlein, Arthur Clarke but I don't really keep up. I just read or reread some of Gordon Dixon's child's cycle and I'm impressed with a broad optimistic view of human change and evolution he's presenting. What about New Wave authors? I guess a new wave technically is passed, I suppose. I think so. What was your response to that? I felt that the New Wave was—well, I was sort of anti-New Wave because I felt that the New Wave people were—first of all they were intensely pessimistic about science and They were trying to throw out the traditional, accepted literary patterns that at least were accepted by me and used in the field. And turning back to literary experiments by people like Dos Pasos and James Joyce who had been tried a generation ago and they were brought on as they were something new again. but I think by and large, well let's say, some of the new wave writers were very able and the impact of the new world has been, a new wave has been to improve the, well, the awareness of literary values of style and so forth so by and large it's been a quote good thing. Is it possible to blend, say, the mainstream or the new wave attempt with good science fiction? Are they mutually exclusive or is it possible possible to have good mainstream material at science fiction? Well, I'm not enthusiastic about consolidating mainstream literature and science fiction, but I also remember that there was a time when science fiction wasn't rolled of in the category by itself and I don't think there's any reason it should be. When Wells was publishing his stories, they were just novels or romances or whatever. The science fiction was in a sort of ghetto, quote ghetto, for a generation. I think this was partly due to the fact that this published in book magazines and people looked down on the books. I think we're sort of getting over that, but it's still a category, a publisher's category like westerns or gothics and love romances or whatever. That means that if Don Wilhelm or Judith Lynn Del Rey or someone else packages a book in a recognizable science fiction package, it'll sell enough copies to make a profit. And I saw a limited profit because it is shelled in the science fiction racks in the stands and the general public doesn't see it. So people who get to be bestsellers, successful, people like Vonnegut and so forth, tend to want to get the science fiction label off their stories when they begin to sell enough copies. but I've never reached that stage myself. I'm proud to have mine called science fiction. Well, you mentioned the general public. Probably the general public wouldn't be included as, say, fans of science fiction. Is science fiction always going to be a separate thing? Is it still separate where you have to be a member almost of a cult or an in-group? Well, let's say some science fiction is. I think one thing, the most important thing that's happened to the field is the diversification of it. Instead of having one readership, we have many readerships. There's a limited group that are interested in, let's say, the possibilities of hard science. In Syria, they look at science fiction to explore possibilities of future social evolution, cultural change, of the times of the psychological impact of new technologies and everything. And there're more people who are interested in characterization and story value and maybe literature has escaped so I think that we won't just have one science fiction, but many varieties of it. But it seems to me that as far as I can see ahead, there should be a public for, quote, science fiction, just as there still is for Westerns or mysteries or other identifiable categories. You don't see a more, say comparing, you're uniquely qualified to do this, say comparing the readership of science fiction today with say back in the 30s or early 40s, Wouldn't you say a greater proportion of the population reads and appreciates science fiction than did they have? I think so. When I started, nobody knew what it was, you had to explain it. There was one science fiction magazine, though some science fiction stories were running magazines like Galaxy and people like Wells and Conan Doyle have been publishing occasionally science fiction, not for a specialized audience, all along. But certainly, there are more people reading it now than there ever were before but there are a lot more people who see it on TV or see I got some science fiction movies than ever reading. When you got a convention these days where the Star Trek fans and the comic book fans and the Star Wars fans and so forth, so that number of the science fiction fans. A couple of weeks ago I was at a convention in Phoenix that was attended by I think about 800 people and I was really And I was probably the only identifiable hard science fiction writer there. They were Star Wars characters. There were comic books authors and so forth who have the big public. I'm no complaint about that. You don't think that hurts, uh, the kind of science fiction that you value more, say the movies, the television, that kind of material? Well, movies have very seldom been good science fiction. There have been a few good science fiction films but science fiction, of the sort I like, has been called a literature of ideas, and to some extent it is. The films I think necessarily deal not in ideas but with emotions, with sensation. I just saw the shining, and I liked it as a superb piece of filmatic craftsmanship. inaudible 007 dot com. The shop socks of the audience, by and large as well. There are people who feel it neglected characterization and feel that the explanation of the supernatural is not consistent. But I feel that he knew what he was doing and he did it. Considering consistency, where it seems to me that he was making a deliberate appeal to the irrational, to the inexplicable, and to the totally mysterious, if he tried to explain all the ghosts in the old hotel, then why he would have been laying down the suspense at the same time. So, I love it. But… Do you think there have been any successful science fiction movies and good ones? 2001, I think, was tremendous. There are a number of others that are regarded as classics. But typically the movies and TV haven't done what might have been done. In the first year or two of Star Trek, and they were buying professionally published science fiction stories. Stories written by professional writers. I thought many of them were pretty good. Gradually, as time went on, they went more and more into the standard Hollywood format and had less and less originality and creativity. and so forth. Well, space 1999 and about a star galactica, that is they have a plenty of money for all sorts of expensive special effects but they have a content for the intelligence to the audience. That is, they don't care about ideas, about consistency, or whatever. All they're trying to do is create emotional effect that if you know too much science or care too much about believability, well, the emotional effect doesn't work. I'm about to ask a very broad question so you can feel free to edit it down to a better size. What do you think goes into making a good science fiction story? Tom Warsinger Well of course I'm something of believer myself in emotional effects. That is, you need a strong conflict and you need something that will involve the reader emotionally so that you need characters that he can either hate or identify with. And you need some sense of originality. if you get something new, but that is not always possible. I tend myself to, well, to look for a theme for some sort of significant statement about science or the future or the of the impact of science and technology on individual human beings, on human life, on society, on what the world might be. But I think all that is important is for the writer to be genuinely interested in what he is saying about something relevant to science and technology and change, it seems to me the essential thing is probably that science fiction recognizes that the world is changing under the impact of technology. The future is going to be different and the mainstream main audience either doesn't know this or prefers to forget it or whatever. That's a good distinction to make. I was going to ask you, is that something you presented in your classes when you taught science fiction, that it's concerned with change and distinction of mainstream material? Speaking of your teaching, why do you think science fiction, say, should be taught, say, as far down as junior high, junior high, high school, college? Is there any particular value it can offer students? Well, I think that assuming that science fiction does deal with change, the world is really changing. so the recognition of this is a element of reality or realism that you don't have in a lot of classic literature And kids growing up are going to be living in a world that's different from the world around them now It seems to me they have a legitimate interest in what the future is going to be And in a practical teaching situation, you're trying to pull kids off the playground out of the front of the TV and teach them to read, to understand, and to think and sometimes this is pretty difficult. I've tried various approaches to various literary figures and periods and some of them work very well and some of them don't, and it seems to me that science fiction all the way offers a sort of bridge or a door or whatever to the interests of a lot of students that you don't have if you try to go back to Shakespeare, let's say. Yes, I think one thing science fiction forces a person who's reading it to do is to think about the future and to think about the world he's living in is related to the future. I think that's basically what it's about really, as much as you say it's about anything. And it seems to me that generally you can classify it more or less as utopian or dystopian, that is that you can look for some assumption that technology is good or that technology is bad, that the future is going to be better or the future is going to be worse, or that the human being is helpless victim of his environment and his own nature, or that he can make significant decisions and change his environment and make things better than there were. That was basically the approach I took in my classes. I like to begin with the second two books on Father's Progress. It was written a deliberate criticism of the early scientists to the Royal Society and so forth, to present, as far as I could, selected stories that would be briefed on both sides, dystopias and utopias optimism and pessimism selection from such people as well Clark and Heinlein and so forth on one side and made my own and all that plenty of dystopian fiction usually better written and more engaging than the optimistic well though if you're going to categorize like that say you put Wells and Huxley and Swift maybe Ellison on the one hand maybe Heinlein Asimov people like that on the other I would put you on that side the second side with the Optimist or the Utopian ultimately even though you did write the humanoids well that's where I'd like to be okay that's fair but I've only got one more question I'm done I don't know the tapes brought out too um maybe I misinterpreted something you wrote, Dr. Williamson, but I thought I read somewhere where you were skeptical of the possibility of finding intelligent alien life elsewhere. No, I don't. I don't think I... Well, I'm skeptical about our actually finding it because the universe is so vast and communication is so difficult. There are two chains of probability or whatever. there's it it's been proven that the must say the stuff of life originates elsewhere even then galactic clouds before there any planets so the stuff of life is there and what I have to theoretically develop on on any planet according to the best that there is really the galaxy is full of planets so It ought to be there. But on the other hand, we have a record of evolution for an four and a half billion years or whatever in the solar system and there's no evidence that anything alien ever turned up here. And at our best speeds so far, it will take many thousand years to get to another world. And I'm just skeptical that the flying saucers are interplanetary visitors or whatever. But I can see a possibility of, let's say, radio communication or picking up radio signals or laser signals or something else. But it also seems that this would have to go at the speed of light, which takes 100,000 years to cross the galaxy. So any very intimate conversation would take a lot of time. Well, you've invented a couple ways for people to go faster than light, haven't you? Yes. I'm very fond of Jerry Fineberg for the invention of the talked to you on. And I've invented other devices of my own, and I regard these as necessary for pieces of fictional machinery, but I'm not sure they're going to work in reality. People keep saying that the Einstein speed of life limit is not absolute, but there's a good deal to be said for it in practical terms. But to summarize, in other words, you're not skeptical about the existence or the possibility of intelligent life, just that we would be able to contact it. Right, that's the right. I don't see why it shouldn't be there. Of course, there's a sort of appalling possibility There's an opportunity to see the possibility that an evolving species opens up the atom and commits instantaneous suicide, but you can hope that wouldn't always happen.

they could.

some more and moved to Beverly Hills in the meantime and stayed another year. The psychiatrist
in the story is now reflects some attitudes toward Dr. Tidd.
I think it's probably unfair or unfair to him to say that, but it seems to me that looking
back now at the story and what he tries to say, Will Barbee starts up in terror of the
forces of darkness, and in the end, he finds he is part of them.
And that, in a way, is reflection of my own experience.
I can remember a time when I felt that I was involved in a strong conflict between will
and emotion where I made resolutions that were difficult to keep and felt sort of divided
against myself.
I feel that I got to be all better integrated so that I am no longer subconscious of internal
conflicts or wanting to do things that I do not do or attempting to make resolutions that
that I wouldn't be able to keep.
I just have a degree of acceptance of myself,
of the unconscious, of the whole human nature?
That I didn't have.
I think that's probably the basic
emotional structure of the novel.
You weren't attempting then to …
Did you have any serious ideas about
the lycanthropy, the werewolf,
that that was the reason for it?
that kind of genetic inheritance?
Well, I think the lycanthropy is an excellent or apt or whatever symbol for,
let's say, the quote, dark forces of the unconscious.
And I didn't certainly have any serious, but belief in magic or lycanthropy
It was pure fantasy or science fiction, but unfortunate invention because it was symbolic and expressive and so in its own way true.
To go forward a little bit, another book I wanted to ask you about is Brother to Demon, Brother to Gods, more or less on genetic engineering and so forth.
I took that book as fairly optimistic in its ending.
I think it is. It was meant to be. I'm certainly interested in genetic engineering.
It seems to me that well the big scientific event, well 40 years ago when it happened,
was the splitting of the atom, and unraveling of DNA is, has somewhat more profound consequences
when we began to realize them.
And years ago, I wrote a novel,
in which, well, so far as I know,
but it invented the term genetic engineering,
or it had probably been around in other works,
called Dragon's Island.
But that was published in 51,
which was a couple of years before Watson and Craig
made that great breakthrough.
And then more recently, I decided to come back to it and to push the possibilities of
genetic engineering as far as I could imagine them.
Would you accept it?
I mean, is it something you're for?
Well, I don't think it's a matter of being for it or not.
I think it's going to happen.
I think that people are going to be opposed to it and there'll be conflicts and so forth,
but assuming that science and technology remain alive,
well, I think genetic engineering is going forward.
It has so many possible uses in the manufacture of insulin,
the manufacture of interferon,
and the possibilities for, let's say,
improving health and happiness,
and comfort and longevity are so vast
that you can't imagine people refusing to do it,
and if we go ahead with it,
it involves the potential of improving or changing
and tinkering with the human germplasm
and rebuilding the race itself.
As I said, it's fascinating to watch,
and in the story of us set up the Smithwick family
as the creators and have them
recreating their own children
so they would be better genetic engineers
generation after generation.
I set up these four creations.
The true men who were genetically perfect,
who were happy and smart and peaceful
and good citizens of society
and the new men who were specialized
for space or warfare or anything else.
And the gods ruled and then discovering that the gods
were created a little bit too much in the image of man
so that there needs to be another creation
to supplant the gods.
And the gods naturally don't want to be supplanted.
And it struck me that this was, let's say,
a beautiful dramatic situation with the essence of conflict
of conflict and discovery and revelation
where these two naked kids on the preman reservation
faced with the problem of keeping alive
when the gods are after them
to grow up and discover what they are
and might make the old a man to replace the gods.
It was just fun to do, let's say.
And I wouldn't say that it's possible
But I wouldn't say it's impossible.
That is, I think that it is imaginative exploration of what could happen.
Would you say in that book that man is sort of controlling his own evolution?
Well, it seems to me we can control our own evolution.
And that, in a way, is not very remarkable,
because for many thousands of years,
We've been controlling the evolution of horses and cattle and dogs and so forth, so that
obviously human evolution can be controlled, and since we're discovering, let's say decoding
the genetic message, where we can do it more effectively and genetically, effectively and
efficiently, than it was already done before.
What about, this isn't exactly the same kind of material, but it is in a way,
that story on Guinevere for Everybody about cloning.
Is cloning something you can foresee as possible or good?
I can't really see any good in it or not much good anyway, but it seems to me it's
possible we can already clone frogs and with continual refinement and
laboratory processes and understanding and so forth I can see cloning human
beings but a human clone as far as I can see is is essentially an identical
or a queen and not a sort of supernatural second self.
So, assuming that you had clones, it seems
to me that they would have to be grown up individually
and educated individually.
And they would not be doppelgangers or second selves
or instant duplicates of the donor, or whatever.
You can't see why it shouldn't happen.
It seems to me that there's a possibility of using the cloning technique to, for example,
to grow a new heart that would be a perfect replacement of a normal heart because it's
grown out of the same tissue and such things as this.
It might be possible to grow a whole series of implants and replacements that would make
make life go on almost essentially forever.
As far as I know, the brain cells are not replaceable
and they won't live forever.
So I can't see that as a real way to immortality.
One more question on this particular point.
Say in reference to cloning or genetic engineering,
would you say that there is no area of science that man,
I mean man can monkey with anything he wants, is there anything which we shouldn't touch which
would be wrong for science to meddle with or monkey with? Well I suppose I'm sort of a relativist,
maybe I'm a Darwinian evolutionist. It's hard to find any absolute symbols or standards or whatever
of what is wrong and right.
If you look at the whole evolutionary picture
why some things, patterns of growth
and ways of behavior and so forth
lead to the survival of the individual
and the species and some don't.
That's one available standard of behavior
and if you look at that
why the technology seems likely to survive
and prevail unless they destroy themselves.
And whatever is going to destroy the race is obviously bad in that way,
and it seems to me when we open the atom, we're skating on thin ice,
and there might be similar hazards in genetic engineering.
That is, theoretically, we could design a form of life that would wipe us out.
Maybe we will.
Maybe we need the humanoids to keep us from doing that.
That's what they're for.
But personally, being a sort of individualist,
I hate to give up completely to the humanoids.
There is one more work.
I keep forgetting about this one, the CT work, CT ship, CT shock.
Is that the way that's pronounced, by the way?
CT? Contra-terrine matter?
Yes, it was abbreviated contra-terrine with the letters C and T,
and I just spelled it out. That was a work I did for Kamel
and I enjoyed doing it. I went to him with the idea for a series of
stories about the planetary engineers who would terraform new worlds. That is, would
rebuild them, tinker with the atmosphere, the chemistry, maybe the
gravitation whatever, to make them suitable for human settlement.
And Cummel suggested that some of these new worlds
might be CT, that is, Aided Matter,
which was pretty new to science fiction then.
I was fascinated, and I did a series of stories
and then a serial that eventually became two novels.
Where did you come up with the concept terraform?
Did you coin that word?
As far as I know, I invented the word.
My name is David and you began to recite a few such terms that I think I can claim credit
for such as terraforming and psionics, and the android is distinct from Robert and so
forth.
Didn't the CT novel and the short stories lead into a syndicated strip in the newspapers?
that was exciting adventures. I was sitting at my desk one day when a phone rang and the editor of the New York Sunday news was on the line
and wanted to know if I would come to New York and write a comic strip. And I caught my breath and said I would,
and they had read one of the CT novels reviewed in the New York Times by a rather superior
reviewer, and said that the plot was pretty interesting, but the way of writing made it
look like a science fiction comic strip.
And this was in the early days of commercial TV, when people were turning on the tube on
Sunday morning instead of writing the Sunday news.
Somebody thought that if it had exclusive strips instead of
syndicated strips that everybody else had.
It might give them a competitive age.
They originally planned for new comics
including a Western and a Mystery and Adventure, I think,
but the science fiction was the only one they did.
It ran for three years, but eventually didn't turn out
to be the answer to TV.
the artist was Lee Elias who used to work with MLK Niff on Terry and the Pirates and has a nice
clean cut style and was good with new and strange characters and good with machines and the thing
was fun to do. My heart was broken when it ended because I'd come to enjoy getting my regular check.
it was at that time that I went back part-time into the academic world. I started taking
college courses while the strip was running because it didn't take all my time to write
it. I asked for a graduate assistantship and math and they didn't have one, but I was
was that I just stared to one in English which turned out to be a fortunate choice
and the academic world did mesh very well with writing.
It's wonderful to be paid to read good literature and talk about it with a congenial group of
students.
And I enjoyed teaching and found that I was able to continue writing during holidays and
vacations.
and maybe I learned a little bit more about literature and about people and so forth.
It was a very happy experience.
Didn't you also put together one of the first courses on science fiction?
I think so.
Mark Heligance at Colgate University wrote the first one that I knew about.
It was written up in the National Server and I kept the article out
I showed it to the curriculum committee and my chairman at Eastern and I got approval
for a course.
What time was that?
That was, let's see, Helligus started his course in 1962 and I started mine in
1964 and taught it for a dozen years, spent part of those years doing all I could to promote
academic science fiction elsewhere
and accumulated descriptions of other
courses and lectured
and published articles
and finally put together
a textbook for science fiction
teachers and anthology of articles
by Likes
of Asimov and Gwynn and Gunn
and others that
has finally been published
I have a question
about your own opinion
this may not be a fair question to ask of an author,
but do you have favorite books, favorite stories, characters,
as you look back, that you would, say, like most to be remembered for?
Many of my own.
Yeah, on your own. Yes.
I think darker than you think is probably the thing, the novel,
that, let's say, fell into place most pleasingly.
When I look back on it, it seems still to work. It's still engaging and still means something.
Humanoids has been my most successful, most widely translated novel, but the original Novelette with folded hands said essentially what I wanted to say in more compact and satisfying ways
so that I always felt the novelette was a better story than the novel.
That, in a way, has been my most successful and popular work.
The novelette has been reprinted many, many times.
How many languages has the humanoid been translated into it?
Well, I don't know, but most of the Western European languages and Japan,
and let's see, it's just going into several Croatians and Hebrew.
But it's gotten around.
I want to add something about your working method.
When you come up with a concept for a story, you know, whatever it is,
you know, CT or humanoids, whatever,
do you get a concept and then find a story to fit it,
or do you have a story that you shove the concept into?
Is there...
Well, I'd like to say I think that it just grows.
I often began with some sort of abstract idea,
like the conflict or primitivism and progress, or whatever,
and I looked for the essence of conflict in the basic idea,
and then tried to find characters of forces
that would embody this conflict,
and in the early stages of it,
why the whole thing is very flexible, almost flimsy.
You can do anything to it if you want to, turn it inside out.
But if it works, it gradually comes alive and the characters become real.
They, until, they are, well, human beings that I feel that I know,
and it sort of, change becomes very difficult to make.
I noticed looking over some of your manuscripts
at Eastern New Mexico University
that you do revise.
It seems to me that you had revised.
Is that a normal process of your writing to go back over?
More and more.
In the beginning, I saw myself as a pulp writer.
My idols in the pulp field were such figures as Max Brand,
who was said to write 4,000 words every day,
including Sundays and he sent it out in rough draft.
The course of his life, he said it would have published
between 30 and 40 million words.
And I tried to do that for years,
and sometimes believe it or not, it worked.
Most of my work for several years was submitted
in the first draft and often accepted and liked
by the fans, but as time goes on, I change.
The market changes.
changes I become I guess more conscious of technique and the ways that things can go
wrong. So now a day it's when I write a paragraph, I have a tendency to take it apart and rewrite
it instead of going wrong, which was one reason for buying this new word processor, because
it seems to facilitate the revision immensely. You compose on a monitor and if you don't
like what you see there, where you can over-type it
or delete it or whatever,
and save whatever's good without having to re-type it.
How do you keep up with science?
You must have a fairly extensive scientific background,
or any good science fiction writer must.
Well, I've always been, as I said,
fascinated with science as a sort of unfolding mystery.
that is I want to know as much as I can about
the nature and the origins of the universe.
I subscribe to a whole group of magazines,
Science News, Scientific American Science,
which is the publication of the American Association for the Advancement of Science,
which is, which I'm pretty technical,
but some things I can read and understand.
I subscribe to a couple of astronomy magazines.
I subscribe to a couple of computer magazines.
since I bought the word processor and occasionally I get off to other events.
My wife and I attended the Jupiter flyby at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory March, a year
ago, and got a short story out of that that I called it Descent into the Great Red Spot
though I think that's changing the name of it and we've been invited back to the Saturn
and fly by come November and something like that,
which gives you an opportunity to see actual science
at work, and science unfolding
is about as exciting as anything could be.
The Jupiter flyby, while the pictures of Jupiter
and its satellites were coming in on the monitors,
one every 48 seconds.
Most of them you knew would never be seen again.
And there were select some for more study,
but most of them would disappear.
And it was just exciting.
It was like exploring a new solar system.
These satellites up to that time had just been
spots of light in the telescope,
and at the nearest best approaches
it was you could see details just a few kilometers across.
And each satellite was different,
with a different history, with different clues about the origins of itself
and the whole solar system and maybe the universe.
Things like that might make science as interesting as anything I know.
To change the subject again, let's see, if I remember now,
you have been president of the Science Fiction Writers Association, or you still are?
I finished my second term less than a month ago.
I hope now to get back to more science fiction.
The term is for how long?
Each term is for only one year.
It was a very rewarding experience.
I guess I have said before science fiction is a pretty small, friendly, close community
and a lot of people in it have been good friends over the years.
and it was an opportunity to try to do something for science fiction.
But it took a bit of the time.
What were your duties, if you don't mind me breaking in?
We have about 500 members.
We have all sorts of activities.
One of the most important is a grievance committee
that tries to, let's say, avoid difficulties with editors and publishers
and so forth.
but to make sure that they treat us right.
We have the nebula awards that are given each year
to recognize working the field.
We attempt to also publicize and propagandize science fiction.
And there are many, many people in our organization
who devote a lot of priceless time and energy to this,
but the whole thing has to be coordinated
and people drop out and have to be replaced and misunderstandings develop that have to
be somehow explained and new projects come along that need to be supported.
There wasn't any one thing that took a great deal of time, but there was a continual flow
of problems and minor decisions and so forth, so that every week I'd have to spend maybe
a couple of days catching up on the mail and phone calls, and whatever.
What are the criteria for membership? Does everybody who, is everybody automatically
a member who publishes a story or does it have to take application or.
you make application, and an affiliate member has to have at least one story professionally published,
and an active member the requirement for that is three stories, short stories, or short works that
doesn't have to be fiction stories or a longer works such as a novel or whatever. The deals now
now, of forty dollars a year, and we have two publications, a monthly, well, between
them, they're monthly, a forum that is essentially for the members with official business and
market reports and whatever, and a bulletin that comes out four times a year that is devoted
devoted to more general articles, background material on science and science fiction.
And the members usually have privilege to attend the Safwa Suite at a convention and
let's say membership is a sort of ticket to the club that I regard as exciting to belong to.
You said there are some 500 members?
Yes.
That must be the largest, uh...
obviously the largest it's ever been, probably.
Yes, it's still growing steadily.
The science fiction market, well, until the last year or so, was booming.
Various publishers, paperback publishers,
had regular plans to publish four, six, sometimes eight titles a month.
that, Willie Charlie Brown of Locust was keeping a record of the books published and that kept
growing until the total passed a thousand a year, about half re-print and half new,
including fantasy as well as science fiction.
I think that, well, since the depression, or whatever it was, where many publishers
have cut back their schedules, it is a little harder for a new writer to break in than it
was, but it's still a very profitable and exciting field compared to what it was.
When there was one magazine, I got 25 bucks for my first story.
Of course, the big money is from films and TV and such things as that.
I know you said that it's hard for you to keep up with everything that's being published
today, but do you have any particularly favorite authors, the younger ones, say, starting in
the last 10 years or so, that you think are going to be valuable?
Well, I don't follow well enough to say anything very intelligent.
When I was teaching, I regarded Esther Le Guin's Left Hand of Darkness as the best recent
novel and a great admirer of Heinlein, especially the early Heinlein, Arthur Clarke but I don't
really keep up.
I just read or reread some of Gordon Dixon's child's cycle and I'm impressed with a broad
optimistic view of human change and evolution he's presenting.
What about New Wave authors?
I guess a new wave technically is passed, I suppose.
I think so.
What was your response to that?
I felt that the New Wave was—well, I was sort of anti-New Wave because I felt that
the New Wave people were—first of all they were intensely pessimistic about science and
They were trying to throw out the traditional, accepted literary patterns that at least were accepted by me and used in the field.
And turning back to literary experiments by people like Dos Pasos and James Joyce who had been tried a generation ago and they were brought on as they were something new again.
but I think by and large,
well let's say,
some of the new wave writers
were very able
and the impact
of the new world
has been,
a new wave
has been to improve
the, well,
the awareness
of literary values
of style
and so forth
so by and large
it's been a quote
good thing.
Is it possible
to blend, say,
the mainstream
or the new wave attempt
with good science fiction?
Are they mutually exclusive
or is it possible
possible to have good mainstream material at science fiction?
Well, I'm not enthusiastic about consolidating mainstream literature and science fiction,
but I also remember that there was a time when science fiction wasn't rolled of in the
category by itself and I don't think there's any reason it should be.
When Wells was publishing his stories, they were just novels or romances or whatever.
The science fiction was in a sort of ghetto, quote ghetto, for a generation.
I think this was partly due to the fact that this published in book magazines and people
looked down on the books.
I think we're sort of getting over that, but it's still a category, a publisher's category
like westerns or gothics and love romances or whatever.
That means that if Don Wilhelm or Judith Lynn Del Rey or someone else packages a book in
a recognizable science fiction package, it'll sell enough copies to make a profit.
And I saw a limited profit because it is shelled in the science fiction racks in the stands
and the general public doesn't see it.
So people who get to be bestsellers, successful, people like Vonnegut and so forth, tend to
want to get the science fiction label off their stories when they begin to sell enough
copies.
but I've never reached that stage myself.
I'm proud to have mine called science fiction.
Well, you mentioned the general public.
Probably the general public wouldn't be included as, say, fans of science fiction.
Is science fiction always going to be a separate thing?
Is it still separate where you have to be a member almost of a cult or an in-group?
Well, let's say some science fiction is.
I think one thing, the most important thing that's happened to the field
is the diversification of it.
Instead of having one readership,
we have many readerships.
There's a limited group that are interested in,
let's say, the possibilities of hard science.
In Syria, they look at science fiction
to explore possibilities of future social evolution,
cultural change,
of the times of the psychological impact of new technologies and everything.
And there're more people who are interested in characterization and story value and maybe
literature has escaped so I think that we won't just have one science fiction, but many
varieties of it.
But it seems to me that as far as I can see ahead,
there should be a public for, quote, science fiction,
just as there still is for Westerns or mysteries
or other identifiable categories.
You don't see a more, say comparing,
you're uniquely qualified to do this,
say comparing the readership of science fiction today
with say back in the 30s or early 40s,
Wouldn't you say a greater proportion of the population reads and appreciates science fiction
than did they have?
I think so.
When I started, nobody knew what it was, you had to explain it.
There was one science fiction magazine, though some science fiction stories were running
magazines like Galaxy and people like Wells and Conan Doyle have been publishing
occasionally science fiction, not for a specialized audience, all along. But
certainly, there are more people reading it now than there ever were before but there are a lot more people who see it on TV or see
I got some science fiction movies than ever reading.
When you got a convention these days where the Star Trek fans
and the comic book fans and the Star Wars fans and so forth,
so that number of the science fiction fans.
A couple of weeks ago I was at a convention in Phoenix
that was attended by I think about 800 people and I was really
And I was probably the only identifiable hard science fiction writer there.
They were Star Wars characters.
There were comic books authors and so forth who have the big public.
I'm no complaint about that.
You don't think that hurts, uh, the kind of science fiction that you value more, say
the movies, the television, that kind of material?
Well, movies have very seldom been good science fiction.
There have been a few good science fiction films but science fiction, of the sort I like,
has been called a literature of ideas, and to some extent it is.
The films I think necessarily deal not in ideas but with emotions, with sensation.
I just saw the shining, and I liked it as a superb piece of filmatic craftsmanship.
inaudible 007 dot com.
The shop socks of the audience, by and large as well.
There are people who feel it neglected characterization and feel that the explanation of the supernatural
is not consistent.
But I feel that he knew what he was doing and he did it.
Considering consistency, where it seems to me that he was making a deliberate appeal
to the irrational, to the inexplicable, and to the totally mysterious, if he tried to
explain all the ghosts in the old hotel, then why he would have been laying down the suspense
at the same time.
So, I love it.
But…
Do you think there have been any successful science fiction movies
and good ones?
2001, I think, was tremendous.
There are a number of others that are regarded as classics.
But typically the movies and TV haven't done what might have been done.
In the first year or two of Star Trek,
and they were buying professionally published science fiction stories.
Stories written by professional writers.
I thought many of them were pretty good.
Gradually, as time went on, they went more and more into the standard Hollywood format
and had less and less originality and creativity.
and so forth. Well, space 1999 and about a star galactica, that is they have a plenty
of money for all sorts of expensive special effects but they have a content for the intelligence
to the audience. That is, they don't care about ideas,
about consistency, or whatever. All they're trying to do is create emotional
effect that if you know too much science or care
too much about believability, well, the emotional effect doesn't work.
I'm about to ask a very broad question so you can feel free
to edit it down to a better size.
What do you think goes into making a good science fiction story?
Tom Warsinger Well of course I'm something of believer myself
in emotional effects.
That is, you need a strong conflict and you need something that will involve the reader
emotionally so that you need characters that he can either hate or identify with.
And you need some sense of originality.
if you get something new, but that is not always possible. I tend myself to, well, to
look for a theme for some sort of significant statement about science or the future or the
of the impact of science and technology on individual human beings, on human life, on
society, on what the world might be.
But I think all that is important is for the writer to be genuinely interested in what
he is saying about something relevant to science and technology and change, it seems to me
the essential thing is probably that science fiction recognizes that the world is changing
under the impact of technology. The future is going to be different and the mainstream
main audience either doesn't know this or prefers to forget it or whatever.
That's a good distinction to make.
I was going to ask you, is that something you presented in your classes when you taught
science fiction, that it's concerned with change and distinction of mainstream material?
Speaking of your teaching, why do you think science fiction, say, should be taught, say, as far down as junior high, junior high, high school, college?
Is there any particular value it can offer students?
Well, I think that assuming that science fiction does deal with change, the world is really changing.
so the recognition of this is a element of reality or realism that you don't have in a lot of classic literature
And kids growing up are going to be living in a world that's different from the world around them now
It seems to me they have a legitimate interest in what the future is going to be
And in a practical teaching situation, you're trying to pull kids off the playground
out of the front of the TV and teach them to read, to understand, and to think and sometimes
this is pretty difficult.
I've tried various approaches to various literary figures and periods and some of them work
very well and some of them don't, and it seems to me that science fiction all the way
offers a sort of bridge or a door or whatever to the interests of a lot of students that
you don't have if you try to go back to Shakespeare, let's say.
Yes, I think one thing science fiction forces a person who's reading it to do is to think
about the future and to think about the world he's living in is related to the future.
I think that's basically what it's about really, as much as you say it's about anything.
And it seems to me that generally you can classify it more or less as utopian or dystopian,
that is that you can look for some assumption that technology is good or that technology is bad,
that the future is going to be better or the future is going to be worse,
or that the human being is helpless victim of his environment and his own nature,
or that he can make significant decisions and change his environment and make things better than there were.
That was basically the approach I took in my classes.
I like to begin with the second two books on Father's Progress.
It was written a deliberate criticism of the early scientists to the Royal Society and
so forth, to present, as far as I could, selected stories that would be briefed on both sides,
